title: In this issue of  Occupational Medicine
abstract:

Province of central China), presents significant public
health challenges not only in china but across all affected
countries worldwide. Koh [
text: The recent COVID-19 outbreak in Wuhan city (HubeiProvince of central China), presents significant publichealth challenges not only in china but across all affectedcountries worldwide. Koh [                The future of the NHS is discussed in an insightfuleditorial by Andrew Goddard, President of the RoyalCollege of Physicians [                The agricultural sector and associated industriesrepresent important segments of many developing anddeveloped economies. Globally, it is estimated that abouttwo million tons of pesticides are used annually in theseindustries. Notwithstanding the overall positive benetfisthat the sector brings to society, results of epidemiologicalstudies have suggested that associations exist betweenoccupational pesticide exposure and human ill-health. Intheir systematic review and meta-analysis, Ratanachinaet  al. [                Similarly, Perić and Vukomanović Đurđević [                Work-related musculoskeletal disorder (WRMD)remains a signicfiant problem in many healthcare workers.While the majority of conditions are preventable, there isgrowing concern about the prevalence of WRMD insurgeons. Grant et al.’s Australian study [                On a similar theme Lawson [                López-Bueno et al.’s study [        Finally, SOM too recognises that the outbreak ofCOVID-19 represents a significant and urgent threat toglobal health, and OUP has joined with the Wellcometrust, universities, research funders, and scholarlypublishers to ensure that research findings and data relevantto this outbreak are shared rapidly and openly to informthe public health response. See https://academic.oup.com/journals/search-results?q=coronavirus&fl_SiteID=5567&SearchSourceType=1&allJournals=1&sort=Date+%e2%80%93+Newest+First. This content is displayed in addition toOUP’s own hub https://academic.oup.com/journals/pages/coronavirus.Gordon Jackson-KokuFiller ArticlesOccupational Medicine seeks authors to write interestingor amusing filler articles for its white spaces. Wewelcome contributions on topics related to occupationalmedicine or medical matters. Or you may have aninteresting story to tell about why you became anoccupational physician. All contributions must be lessthan 500 words. If you have something to contribute,please contact us at om@som.org.uk.
